awd_titl_txt: Research Experience for Undergraduates in UAV Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (CPP) continues to increase undergraduate students’ participation in research projects on unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) technologies. Undergraduate students from 2-and 4-year institutions with limited or no research opportunities will continue to be involved in UAV research projects in a multidisciplinary environment. UAVs have potential to replace manned aircraft for many dull, dirty, and dangerous missions such as surveillance of disaster-hit areas, search and rescue, package delivery, traffic monitoring, remote sensing, precision agriculture, crop dusting, border patrol, battlefield damage assessment, and supply missions. UAVs are cheaper than manned aircraft and pose no risk to human operators. The UAV industry is one of the fastest growing sectors of aerospace industries. However, there is a lack of students entering the workforce or graduate schools in this area. The proposed REU Program is designed to increase students’ interest in UAV technologies by means of first-hand experience on UAV research with direct mentorship by faculty advisors. This will be helpful in preparing a strong workforce for future needs of the aerospace industry, which is facing an aging workforce. This will also be helpful encouraging them to pursue their studies for graduate degrees. This is important as the interest among students for graduate degrees is declining. The strong workforce that this REU Site will prepare will help mature the UAV technologies for mass adoption of UAVs for various applications.

This REU Site offers undergraduates opportunities to conduct research during a 10-week summer program on cutting edge topics in UAV flight dynamics and control, increased UAV autonomy, collision detection and avoidance, computer vision, artificial intelligence, and aerospace robotics. Students will also get opportunities to learn about Federal regulations pertaining to the operation of UAVs. In addition to their research, students will participate in weekly research seminars, research meetings, and professional development seminars that are designed to prepare a strong workforce for the needs of industry and academia. The seminars will include topics such as literature review, writing a scientific paper, improving written and oral communication skills, technical presentations, applications to graduate schools, opportunities for research/teaching assistantships and fellowships, career paths, resume building, team building, and ethics in science and engineering. The participants will also engage in outreach activities and give presentations on UAV technologies to K-12 students at local schools. This will enhance students' communication skills, allow them to see the broader implications of their research, and see how they can positively impact society through research.

This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site offered research experiences to undergraduates in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) technologies in a multidisciplinary environment. The Site exposed undergraduates including underrepresented students from 2- and 4-year institutions with limited or no research opportunities to state-of-the-art in UAV technologies. The Program involved more than 50% students from underrepresented groups and 33% women. The students were carefully mentored by an interdisciplinary team of faculty members from Aerospace Engineering, Electrical & Computer Engineering, and Computer Science Departments. The learner-centered and team-based summer research program covered a wide range of disciplines such as Flight Dynamics, Guidance, Navigation, and Control, Computer Vision, Autonomy, Aerospace Robotics, Artificial Intelligence, Modeling & Simulation, Collision Detection and Avoidance, Localization and Mapping, Fire Detection, Monitoring, and Suppression, Flight Testing, etc. Students learned fundamental skills in engineering and computer science, and were trained to use computational tools needed to engage in multidisciplinary UAV research. Students also learned to do scientific literature review, and gained skills in technical paper writing and presentation.

In addition to their research, students participated in weekly research seminars, research meetings, and professional development seminars. The seminars included topics such as literature review, writing a scientific paper, improving written and oral communication skills, technical presentations, graduate education, career paths, resume building, and ethics in science and engineering. The participants also engaged in K-12 outreach. They presented their research on UAV technologies to High School students. The participants were provided with an opportunity to visit research labs and aerospace industry involved in UAV research & development including Lockheed Martin Corporation and Northrop Grumman Corporation. The research projects combined with professional development opportunities helped us shape their future career in industry, Government agencies, and academia.

The participants who have so far graduated with a BS degree in Engineering or Computer Science, some are pursuing full-time studies for graduate degrees in the area of UAVs, Computer Science, or related areas.  Others joined aerospace industry involved in UAV research & development, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, and other related industries.  All of the participants from Community Colleges have already transferred to 4-year institutions including Cal Poly Pomona for BS degrees in Engineering or Computer Science. All of the graduated and non-graduated participants are planning to pursue their studies for graduate degrees, either full-time or part-time. Participants who have not yet graduated or are graduating soon were or have been accepted for summer internship and full-times positions at companies such as Northrop Grumman Corporation, Lockheed Martin Corporation, and The Boeing Company. All of these companies are heavily involved in UAV research and development. Some of the participants have been continuing their research projects during the academic year (s) and/or during summer.

UAVs have potential to replace manned aircraft for applications such as surveillance of disaster-hit areas, search & rescue, package/cargo delivery, traffic monitoring, remote sensing, precision farming, border patrol, battlefield damage assessment, and supply missions. UAVs are significantly cheaper than manned aircraft and pose no risk to human operators. The UAV industry is one of the fastest growing sectors of aerospace industries. However, there is a lack of students entering the workforce or graduate schools in this area. At the current pace, the work force requirement of the growing UAV sector cannot be achieved. The REU program was designed to increase students' interest in UAV technologies by means of first-hand research experience on UAV research in a multidisciplinary environment with direct mentorship by faculty advisors from various departments within the CPP Colleges of Engineering and Science. The Program helped develop a trained workforce to meet the requirements of this growing sector. This will have significant impact on society as the strong workforce will also be responsible for the safety of the UAVs and safety and privacy of public. Increased use of UAVs will reduce the cost for a number of aforementioned missions, thereby helping reduce the Government spending at Federal, State, and Local levels for these missions.  

 The REU Program also helped us involve additional students from Community Colleges and High Schools for summer research experience. They were supported by internal sources and funding from Aerospace Industry. They worked alongside the REU participants. This helped us expose them to current research on UAV autonomy/technology, and their applications, and motivate them to join or transfer to STEM disciplines.

 As only one of the few REUs dedicated to UAV technologies across the nation, the Program served as a role model for others who want to establish UAV research at their institution and/or submit a proposal for REU Site. The Program has been appreciated by the Aerospace Industry alike as the Program was able to prepare graduates who are ready to take higher level of responsibilities than entry-level graduates usually do. The Program has also been helpful in upgrading our labs and getting funding from other Government agencies (State/Federal) or Industry.
